docs.lead_paragraph: LAST month my friend Carole and I paid a long overdue visit to the Osteoporosis Prevention Center at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York to have the density of our bones measured. Carole is 59 and I am approaching 57, and we both should have had this test done for the first time when we entered menopause around age 50, repeating it, if warranted by the initial results and our risk factors, a few years later. But neither of us had any reason to believe our bones would be anything less than perfect. We do not smoke or drink much alcohol and never did. We are not skinny and have never been anorexic. We do weight-bearing exercise every day. We both began estrogen replacement at menopause. Neither of us has a family history of osteoporosis. I have consumed a quart of milk a day for most of my life, and Carole takes a calcium supplement and a multivitamin containing vitamin D and calcium in addition to getting some dietary calcium from yogurt and tofu on most days. Why wouldn't our bones be in great shape?

headline.main: Test at Onset of Menopause Can Avert Bone Loss

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on importance of testing bone density at onset of menopause to help alert individual to possible development of osteoporosis; cautions that concern about bone density should start decades before menopause (M)
docs.snippet: LAST month my friend Carole and I paid a long overdue visit to the Osteoporosis Prevention Center at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York to have the density of our bones measured. Carole is 59 and I am approaching 57, and we both should have...

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that Congress would probably pass health care legislation to protect the rights of patients this year, but he declared that the bill would not solve the problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance companies. Mr. Gingrich made his forecast in a speech to the American Medical Association just five hours after President Clinton received strong support from the same audience for his campaign to pass a ''patient's bill of rights.''

headline.main: Warning and Wooing on Patient Bill of Rights

docs.abstract: Speaker Newt Gingrich says Congress will probably pass legislation to protect patients rights, speech to American Medical Associaiton; indicates he is not enthusiastic, holding bill will not solve problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance companies; Pres Clinton earlier told AMA that bill is needed to require private health plans to provide patients with access to medical specialists and emergency room services, to protect confidentiality of medical records and to guarantee appeal rights for patients denied benefits; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that Congress would probably pass health care legislation to protect the rights of patients this year, but he declared that the bill would not solve the problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: Parisians who shrug in Gallic disdain at the parochial contentedness of life in England could have Ashford in mind. By day, the streets of this tidy market town are filled with shoppers in their patterned flat caps going about their chores at a measured gait. By night the place falls into shuttered stillness. Yet flocks of young men and women are deserting the boulevards of the City of Light to come live and work across the Channel among the once-disparaged ''Rosbifs.'' And this town of 55,000 people amid the sheep meadows and hop gardens of southeastern England has become their unlikely destination.

headline.main: Ashford Journal; Ah, Britain! The Light at the End of the Tunnel

docs.abstract: Ashford, England, has become unlikely destination for hordes of Parisians, who once shrugged in Gallic disdain at parochial contentedness of life in England; migrations are occurring against backdrop of contest between England and France for economic soul of Europe, with many young French men and women traveling to London in search of entry-level jobs unavailable in Paris; town of 55,000 in southeastern England is first British stop for Channel Tunnel passenger trains from France; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Parisians who shrug in Gallic disdain at the parochial contentedness of life in England could have Ashford in mind. By day, the streets of this tidy market town are filled with shoppers in their patterned flat caps going about their chores at a...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 U.S. Offers Russia a Deal To Stop Iran's Missile Plan The United States is offering Russia the opportunity to expand its lucrative business launching foreign satellites if it clamps down on the sale of missile technology to Iran, senior American officials say. The plan is part of broad effort to discourage Russia from helping Iran develop a new surface-to-surface missile. A1 Islamic Women Speak Out More Islamic women's groups are speaking out against what they call the Muslim system of apartheid, where texts of the Koran and a range of appendages attached in the Middle Ages are invoked to deny equal rights to women. The issue of how women are viewed is at the heart of much conflict in Muslim nations, from fundamentalist policies in Afghanistan and Iran to demands to abolish discrimination in family laws in Morocco and Tunisia. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Prisons Replace Hospitals for the Nation's Mentally Ill'' (front page, March 5): Tragic as the situation in Los Angeles is, New York City has nothing to be proud of when it comes to caring for the mentally ill.

headline.main: For Mentally Ill, Freedom Often Leads to Jail; Revolving Door at Rikers

docs.abstract: Heather Barr letter comments on March 5 article on prisons replacing hospitals as places to house nation's mentally ill (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Presidential commission that recommended a bill of rights for patients is now deadlocked on the important question of how to enforce those rights. With its final meeting just a few days away, the panel cannot agree on whether new Federal laws are needed to protect consumers against abuses by health insurance companies, as President Clinton contends.

headline.main: Health Panel at Standstill On Enforcing Bill of Rights

docs.abstract: Presidential commission that recommeded in November 1997 bill of rights for patients is deadlocked on important question of how to enforce rights; cannot agree on whether new Federal laws are needed to protect consumers against abuses by health insurance companies, as Pres Clinton contends; remains deeply divided over need for patient protection law to supplement voluntary efforts of health plans and employers in securing those rights (M)
docs.snippet: A Presidential commission that recommended a bill of rights for patients is now deadlocked on the important question of how to enforce those rights.    With its final meeting just a few days away, the panel cannot agree on whether new Federal laws...

docs.lead_paragraph: St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx was founded in 1866 as the Home for the Incurables, a place where people with cataclysmic strokes or crippling heart disease went to die. By the early 1980's, this anachronism of a hospital might have expired itself, but for its ambitious and enigmatic young president, Dr. Ronald Gade. Dr. Gade tells how he imposed rigorous economies a decade before the rest of New York's health-care industry realized its own bloat. By reducing the size of the staff and discouraging long hospital stays, among other things, he not only saved St. Barnabas; he figured out something few before him had: how to make money -- lots of it -- caring for poor people.

headline.main: Caring for Poor, and for Profit; Bronx Hospital Shakes Up the Medical Establishment

docs.abstract: Article discusses financial turnaround of St Barnabas Hospital in Bronx over last decade under tutelage of president Dr Ronald Gade; he describes series of staff reductions and implementing policy of shorter patient hospital stays as main reasons for hospital's financial success in dealing with poor patients; over last year and a half, St Barnabas has locked up two huge city contracts totaling almost $450 million, one to provide doctors for Lincoln Hospital in South Bronx and other for treating inmates on Rikers Island; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Forty percent fewer children in the state were diagnosed with lead poisoning in 1996 than in 1994, State Health Department officials said. A total of 2,597 children were diagnosed in 1996 with lead poisoning, or 0.59 percent of those screened, according to the Health Department. In 1994, 4,237 tested positive, or about 1 percent of the children screened.

headline.main: State Sees Sharp Drop In Lead Poisoning Rate

docs.abstract: New York State Health Dept reports that 40 percent fewer children in state were diagnosed with lead poisoning in 1996 than in 1994; total of 2,597 children were diagnosed in 1996 with lead poisoning, or 0.59 percent of those screened (S)
docs.snippet: Forty percent fewer children in the state were diagnosed with lead poisoning in 1996 than in 1994, State Health Department officials said.    A total of 2,597 children were diagnosed in 1996 with lead poisoning, or 0.59 percent of those screened,...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was an emergency. Early on a Sunday morning last June, the Minerva and the Bell Ringers clock at Herald Square, near 34th Street and Broadway, went wild, bong bong bonging without stop. Marvin Schneider, the man responsible for the city's most important clocks, was called in. He dashed from his home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, clambered up the clock tower and disabled the striking mechanism, the best he could do on short notice. As he stepped out of the tower into the park, he was astonished to find himself surrounded by six haggard men who apparently lived in the park. ''I thought it was curtains,'' Mr. Schneider said.
docs.abstract: New York City's clock master, Marvin Schneider, is responsible for six city-owned clocks, as well as unofficial caretaker of eight more, including Bell Ringers clock at Herald Square; 58-year-old retired city employee happened on new occupation out of fascination with clock at 346 Broadway where he worked; he recalls how he and co-worker, Eric Reiner, taught themselves how to fix that clock, largest mechanical one in city, with its four huge faces and eight giant hands; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVELYN MARETH is in the business of improving accuracy: teaching employees how to make fewer errors with data. The vehicle is her company, the Accuracy Company, based in Fairfield. During a recent interview, Ms. Mareth talked about her belief that accuracy is a trainable skill. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

headline.main: Q&A/Evelyn Mareth; Coaxing Meaning From Strings of Digits

docs.abstract: Interview with Evelyn Mareth, who teaches employees of financial institutions and other companies to improve their accuracy with figures; photo; she notes common errors with data, such as transposing digits, putting decimals in wrong place and adding or omitting zeros (M)
